customer_name: Ellie Schiller Homosassa Springs Wildlife State Park

citations.narrative:
The current housing facility for the three manatees “Betsy”, “Ariel”, and “Heinz” continues to not restrict the entrance of
unwanted animals or protect the manatees from injury. Following the previous inspection, the facility added additional fish
exclusion fencing where gaps existed and relocated most of the sheepshead and other larger fish from the manatee
enclosures. The facility stated that three smaller sheepshead fish were still left in the manatee paddock. During the
inspection, APHIS officials witnessed one of these approximately 4” sheepshead fish continuing to pick at the tail wounds
on Betsy and Heinz, along with a different species of fish that was seen picking at the manatees’ wounds and other
surfaces on their bodies. The manatees were seen elevating their tails out of the water in reaction to the fish biting the
wounds located there. The facility also started feeding the manatees in the in-ground (“medical”) pool to help mitigate the
fish presence around the manatees; however, a ~4” grey fish was seen picking at Ariel’s side and tail wounds while she
was in the pool, with resultant hemorrhage. The wounds on the manatees appear largely unchanged since the previous
inspection. While the facility has implemented multiple mitigation measures to reduce the fish burden on the manatees,
there are still fish negatively impacting the manatees at this time.
Allowing unwanted animals access to animal enclosures can lead to pain, discomfort, and ongoing injury. Housing
facilities for marine mammals must be structurally sound and must be maintained in good repair to protect the animals
from injury, to contain the animals within the facility, and to restrict the entrance of unwanted animals.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
Jessica Siegal-Willott n

narrative:
3.101(a)(1)  Direct Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
The current housing facility for the three manatees “Betsy”, “Ariel”, and “Heinz” continues to not restrict the entrance of 
unwanted animals or protect the manatees from injury. Following the previous inspection, the facility added additional fish 
exclusion fencing where gaps existed and relocated most of the sheepshead and other larger fish from the manatee 
enclosures. The facility stated that three smaller sheepshead fish were still left in the manatee paddock. During the 
inspection, APHIS officials witnessed one of these approximately 4” sheepshead fish continuing to pick at the tail wounds 
on Betsy and Heinz, along with a different species of fish that was seen picking at the manatees’ wounds and other 
surfaces on their bodies. The manatees were seen elevating their tails out of the water in reaction to the fish biting the 
wounds located there. The facility also started feeding the manatees in the in-ground (“medical”) pool to help mitigate the 
fish presence around the manatees; however, a ~4” grey fish was seen picking at Ariel’s side and tail wounds while she 
was in the pool, with resultant hemorrhage. The wounds on the manatees appear largely unchanged since the previous 
inspection. While the facility has implemented multiple mitigation measures to reduce the fish burden on the manatees, 
there are still fish negatively impacting the manatees at this time. 
 
Allowing unwanted animals access to animal enclosures can lead to pain, discomfort, and ongoing injury. Housing 
facilities for marine mammals must be structurally sound and must be maintained in good repair to protect the animals 
from injury, to contain the animals within the facility, and to restrict the entrance of unwanted animals. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Jessica Siegal-Willott n
